title: 111_hr1943
content: The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" is the short title of the Act. It includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with adjustments made to rate tables based on minimum and maximum dollar amounts for each rate bracket. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with rate brackets adjusted annually based on multipliers for each statistical area in the United States. The Secretary determines the applicable multiplier for each area by December 15 of each calendar year. If any calculated amount is not a multiple of $50, it is rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with rate brackets adjusted annually based on multipliers for each statistical area in the United States. The applicable multiplier for each area is determined based on cost-of-living differentials, with specific percentages assigned depending on the extent of the differential. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with rate brackets adjusted annually based on multipliers for each statistical area in the United States. The cost-of-living differential for any statistical area for any calendar year is determined by dividing the cost-of-living for the area by the average cost-of-living for the United States. The Secretary of Labor determines and publishes a cost-of-living index for each statistical area annually. The cost-of-living index for any statistical area in the United States is determined based on average market prices for the area for the 12-month period ending on August 31 of the calendar year. The market prices are selected using the same methodology as the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers. The term 'statistical area' includes metropolitan statistical areas defined by the Secretary of Commerce and portions of states not within a metropolitan statistical area. The area applicable multiplier for any area outside the United States is 1. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009, with a transition rule for 2010. The area multiplier outside the US is 1.
